query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Poscia che ’ncontro a la vita presente 2 d’i miseri mortali aperse ’l vero 3 quella che ’mparadisa la mia mente,
4 come in lo specchio fiamma di doppiero 5 vede colui che se n’alluma retro, 6 prima che l’abbia in vista o in pensiero,
7 e sé rivolge per veder se ’l vetro 8 li dice il vero, e vede ch’el s’accorda 9 con esso come nota con suo metro;
10 così la mia memoria si ricorda 11 ch’io feci riguardando ne’ belli occhi 12 onde a pigliarmi fece Amor la corda.
query.result:
**English:**
1 After that she who brought my mind to paradise 2 revealed the truth to the wretched mortals 3 about the present life,
4 just as one sees in a mirror the flame of a torch 5 that he lights behind him, 6 before he has it in sight or in thought,
7 and turns to see if the glass 8 tells him the truth, and sees that it agrees 9 with it as a tune with its meter;
10 so my memory recalls 11 that I looked into the beautiful eyes 12 from which Love made the cord to capture me.
**Cornish:**
1 Wosa henna an ke a wra'n ow paradysi y'm spyrys 2 a wra'n ow diskwedhes an gwir dhe'n veygh marow 3 a-dro dhe'n bys ma'n presens,
4 kepar y'n an mirour tan a wra gweles flam a doppyer 5 a wra'n ow lowenna wosa henna, 6 kyns henna y'n gweles yn golwg po yn poynt,
7 ha'n troha y honan rag gweles po'th an gwydr 8 a wra'n ow leverel an gwir dhe'th, ha'n gweles henna 9 ow kordya gans henna kepar noten gans y meter;
10 kepar henna y'm kov a wra kovsos 11 ow wrug y'm golwg y'n an golgow brav 12 ena'th Amor a wra gwruthyl an kord rag y'm kemeres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 E com’ io mi rivolsi e furon tocchi 14 li miei da ciò che pare in quel volume, 15 quandunque nel suo giro ben s’adocchi,
16 un punto vidi che raggiava lume 17 acuto sì, che ’l viso ch’elli affoca 18 chiuder conviensi per lo forte acume;
19 e quale stella par quinci più poca, 20 parrebbe luna, locata con esso 21 come stella con stella si collòca.
query.result:
**English:**
13 And when I turned and my eyes were touched 14 by what appears in that volume, 15 whenever one looks closely at its turning,
16 I saw a point that radiated light 17 so sharp that the sight that it sets on fire 18 must close because of the strong sharpness;
19 and what seems the smallest star from here 20 would seem like the moon, placed with it 21 as one star is placed with another.
**Cornish:**
13 Ha kepar y'm trohas y'm honan ha'n wra kevys 14 y'm golgow gans henna a wra'n ow tos yn lyver, 15 pub tro ha'n wra golwg yn vyth yn y droyans,
16 y'm gwelas pwynt a wra'n ow radya golow 17 kemmys sharp, kepar an golwg a wra'n ow afya 18 a wra gesys dhe'n drehedha rag an sharpnes kres;
19 ha kepar steren a wra'n ow tos ena moyha poka, 20 a wra'n ow tos kepar loor, settys gans henna 21 kepar steren gans steren a wra settys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Forse cotanto quanto pare appresso 23 alo cigner la luce che ’l dipigne 24 quando ’l vapor che ’l porta più è spesso,
25 distante intorno al punto un cerchio d’igne 26 si girava sì ratto, ch’avria vinto 27 quel moto che più tosto il mondo cigne;
28 e questo era d’un altro circumcinto, 29 e quel dal terzo, e ’l terzo poi dal quarto, 30 dal quinto il quarto, e poi dal sesto il quinto.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Perhaps as much as it seems nearby 23 to the one who sees the light that paints it 24 when the vapor that carries it is thickest,
25 a circle of fire was turning so swiftly 26 around the point, that it would have defeated 27 the motion that most swiftly encircles the world;
28 and this was encircled by another, 29 and that by a third, and the third then by a fourth, 30 the fourth by the fifth, and then the fifth by the sixth.
**Cornish:**
22 Mar pleg vythsa kemmys ythollugh 23 dhe’n kever an golon a’n pynth 24 pan voos an avor a’n portha moyha,
25 ogasowtroha’n poynt o kelgynn tan 26 a wra dha wodha, ow a wra fethys 27 an movyans moyha a wra’n kever an bys;
28 ha henna o kelgynn aral a wra keworrys, 29 ha henna gans tres, ha’n tres gans peswar, 30 an peswar gans pymp, ha’n pymp gans whegh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Sopra seguiva il settimo sì sparto 32 già di larghezza, che ’l messo di Iuno 33 intero a contenerlo sarebbe arto.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Above followed the seventh, so spread out 32 in width, that Juno's messenger 33 would have been too small to contain it entirely.
**Cornish:**
31 A-ugh o kelgynn sethves o ledyas 32 yn-mes, an kengaver a Iuno 33 a via re begh dhe’n jeves dhe vos conteynnya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 La donna mia, che mi vedëa in cura 41 forte sospeso, disse: «Da quel punto 42 depende il cielo e tutta la natura.
query.result:
**English:**
40 My lady, who saw me in such care, 41 deeply concerned, said: "From that point 42 heaven and all nature depend.
**Cornish:**
40 An vraster vy, a welas vy yn-mes 41 yn fethys poyntys, a leveris: «A’n poynt na 42 yma’n kever an nef ha pub an naturel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Mira quel cerchio che più li è congiunto; 44 e sappi che ’l suo muovere è sì tosto 45 per l’affocato amore ond’ elli è punto».
query.result:
**English:**
43 Look at that circle that is closest to it; 44 and know that its movement is so swift 45 because of the fiery love by which it is pricked.
**Cornish:**
43 Gwel an kelgynn na moyha dheuth dhe, 44 ha gwra vythsa moyha moyvya moyha 45 rag an garow karantek owth ena poyntys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Onde, se ’l mio disir dee aver fine 53 in questo miro e angelico templo 54 che solo amore e luce ha per confine,
55 udir convienmi ancor come l’essemplo 56 e l’essemplare non vanno d’un modo, 57 ché io per me indarno a ciò contemplo».
query.result:
**English:**
52 Therefore, if my desire is to have an end 53 in this mirror and angelic temple 54 that has only love and light as its boundaries,
55 I must still hear how the exemplar 56 and the example do not proceed in the same way, 57 because I contemplate this in vain for myself.
**Cornish:**
52 Rag henna, mar ow dysyr dhe vos finya 53 yn an miror ha’n tempel angelik ma 54 owth karantek ha golon a-unys,
55 yth wra rydh dhe’n klevs vythsa pyth yw an ensampel 56 ha’n ensamplir na wra moyvya yn unn fordh, 57 rag vy a-unys a wra kontemplys henna yn van.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 «Se li tuoi diti non sono a tal nodo 59 sufficïenti, non è maraviglia: 60 tanto, per non tentare, è fatto sodo!».
query.result:
**English:**
58 "If your fingers are not sufficient for such a knot, 59 it is no wonder: 60 so much, for not trying, has been made solid!"
**Cornish:**
58 "Mar nyns yw dha dhewgh dhe’n knot na 59 a-les, nyns yw marghas: 60 kemmys, rag na wra provy, yw henna settys kalet!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Così la donna mia; poi disse: «Piglia 62 quel ch’io ti dicerò, se vuo’ saziarti; 63 e intorno da esso t’assottiglia.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Thus my lady; then she said: "Take 62 what I will tell you, if you want to satisfy yourself; 63 and refine yourself around it.
**Cornish:**
61 Henwys ow vraster vy; wosa leveris: "Kemmer 62 henna owth wra leverel dhe’th, mar owth kar dhe vos settys; 63 ha tro-dro dhe henna gwraf vythsa moyha."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Li cerchi corporai sono ampi e arti 65 secondo il più e ’l men de la virtute 66 che si distende per tutte lor parti.
query.result:
**English:**
64 The corporeal circles are wide and narrow 65 according to the more and the less of the virtue 66 that is spread through all their parts.
**Cornish:**
64 An rodoù korporel yw ledan ha kul 65 a-cord dhe’n moyha ha’n lyha a’n vertus 66 owth yw a-stynnys dre pub an rannow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Maggior bontà vuol far maggior salute; 68 maggior salute maggior corpo cape, 69 s’elli ha le parti igualmente compiute.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Greater goodness wants to make greater health; 68 greater health accommodates a greater body, 69 if it has its parts equally complete.
**Cornish:**
67 Mebyonieth brasa a vynnaf brasa iechydh; 68 brasa iechydh a gav dhe gorff brasa, 69 gen dhynner an partow ow kul ow kompletek.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Dunque costui che tutto quanto rape 71 l’altro universo seco, corrisponde 72 al cerchio che più ama e che più sape:
73 per che, se tu a la virtù circonde 74 la tua misura, non a la parvenza 75 de le sustanze che t’appaion tonde,
76 tu vederai mirabil consequenza 77 di maggio a più e di minore a meno, 78 in ciascun cielo, a süa intelligenza».
query.result:
**English:**
70 Therefore, this one, who seizes the entire 71 other universe with him, corresponds 72 to the circle that he loves the most and knows the most:
73 because, if you circumscribe your measure to virtue, 74 not to the appearance 75 of the substances that appear round to you,
76 you will see a marvelous consequence 77 from greater to more and from lesser to less, 78 in each heaven, according to its intelligence.”
**Cornish:**
70 Rag awos hemma, neb a wrapp oll 71 an bys vyth ena ganso, a gompar 72 dhe'n kelgh a gar an moyha ha'n moyha a wodh:
73 rag, gen wrapp dhe vesur dhe'n verthyans, 74 nag dhe'n semlant 75 a'n substansow a wra dhe'n parow ront,
76 why a welo consequens marasek 77 a moyha dhe moyha ha a leha dhe leha, 78 yn pub nef, dhe'y intelligens.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Come rimane splendido e sereno 80 l’emisperio de l’aere, quando soffia 81 Borea da quella guancia ond’ è più leno,
82 per che si purga e risolve la roffia 83 che pria turbava, sì che ’l ciel ne ride 84 con le bellezze d’ogne sua paroffia;
85 così fec’ïo, poi che mi provide 86 la donna mia del suo risponder chiaro, 87 e come stella in cielo il ver si vide.
query.result:
**English:**
79 How splendid and serene the hemisphere 80 of the air remains, when Boreas blows 81 from that cheek from which it is gentlest,
82 because it purges and dissolves the scruff 83 that was troubling it before, so that the sky laughs at it 84 with the beauties of all its parishes;
85 thus I did, after my lady 86 provided me with her clear answer, 87 and like a star in the sky the truth was seen.
**Cornish:**
79 Pythvelyk ha seryn yw hanter-pel 80 an ebron, pan wra Borea sothya 81 a'n fordh na wra moyha gwyns,
82 rag yma'n pur ha'n golli an roffia 83 a wra'n trublya kyns, bytteg an nef 84 gans belethow pub paroffia;
85 hemma wrugof vy, wosa'm provyas 86 an vraster vy gans y hyskleryans kler, 87 ha vel an steren yn nef an gwir a welas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 E poi che le parole sue restaro, 89 non altrimenti ferro disfavilla 90 che bolle, come i cerchi sfavillaro.
query.result:
**English:**
88 And after her words ceased, 89 no differently does iron sparkle 90 that boils, than how the circles sparkled.
**Cornish:**
88 Ha wosa'y gerow hy re beuhes, 89 nag dhefferens, horn a wra'n disfavilla 90 pan wra'n boylya, hemma'n kelghys a wra'n sfavillya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 L’incendio suo seguiva ogne scintilla; 92 ed eran tante, che ’l numero loro 93 più che ’l doppiar de li scacchi s’inmilla.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Its fire followed every spark; 92 and there were so many of them that their number 93 is more similar to the doubling of chess squares.
**Cornish:**
91 Y gynnor y wra'n holyes pub scintilla; 92 ha kemmys o nessa, aga niver 93 a wra moyha ages an dowblya a'n scacchis.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Io sentiva osannar di coro in coro 95 al punto fisso che li tiene a li ubi, 96 e terrà sempre, ne’ quai sempre fuoro.
query.result:
**English:**
94 I heard hosannas from choir to choir 95 at the fixed point that holds them in their places, 96 and will always hold them, in which they always were.
**Cornish:**
94 Y'm klevyas osannas a gor dhe gor 95 dhe'n poynt fiks a wra'n ow holya yn aga le, 96 ha'n wra'n byth ow holya, yn aga bythens o.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 E quella che vedëa i pensier dubi 98 ne la mia mente, disse: «I cerchi primi 99 t’hanno mostrato Serafi e Cherubi.
query.result:
**English:**
97 And she who saw the doubtful thoughts 98 in my mind, said: “The first circles 99 have shown you Seraphim and Cherubim.
**Cornish:**
97 Ha henna a welas an menowgh dubi 98 yn vy menses, a leveris: “An kelghys kynsa 99 a dhiskwedhas Serafim ha Cherubim.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Così veloci seguono i suoi vimi, 101 per somigliarsi al punto quanto ponno; 102 e posson quanto a veder son soblimi.
query.result:
**English:**
100 So swiftly do its spokes follow, 101 in order to resemble the point as much as they can; 102 and they are able to do so as much as they are sublime to see.
**Cornish:**
100 Kemmys a-vel y vimow y gila 101 rag bosvekya dhe'n poynt kemmys a ellons; 102 ha'n ell ymons kemmys yns yns uhella ymons dhe weles.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 L’altro ternaro, che così germoglia 116 in questa primavera sempiterna 117 che notturno Arïete non dispoglia,
118 perpetüalemente ‘Osanna’ sberna 119 con tre melode, che suonano in tree 120 ordini di letizia onde s’interna.
query.result:
**English:**
115 The other ternary, which thus burgeons 116 in this sempiternal spring 117 that the nocturnal Ram does not despoil,
118 perpetually shouts ‘Hosanna’ 119 with three melodies, which resound in three 120 orders of joy in which it is contained.
**Cornish:**
115 An ternari erel, a wra dheudh 116 yn termyn ma bys vyth, 117 na wra’n Hwel Ram nos dheudh,
118 ‘Osanna’ bys vyth a lever 119 gans tri melodi, ow tones yn tri 120 urdh le, ow tressa ynno.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 In essa gerarcia son l’altre dee: 122 prima Dominazioni, e poi Virtudi; 123 l’ordine terzo di Podestadi èe.
query.result:
**English:**
121 In this hierarchy are the other gods: 122 first Dominations, and then Virtues; 123 the third order is that of Powers.
**Cornish:**
121 Yn an hierarki ma'th an dewow erel: 122 kynsa Dominezhiow, ha Virtyujow wosa; 123 an trydydh urdh yw an Potestow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Poscia ne’ due penultimi tripudi 125 Principati e Arcangeli si girano; 126 l’ultimo è tutto d’Angelici ludi.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Then in the two penultimate choirs 125 Principalities and Archangels gyrate; 126 the last is all of Angelic plays.
**Cornish:**
124 Wosa yn an dhew drybudh diwettha 125 Principatow hag Arcangeli a wra dheudh; 126 an diwettha yw oll a lowenj Angelik.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Questi ordini di sù tutti s’ammirano, 128 e di giù vincon sì, che verso Dio 129 tutti tirati sono e tutti tirano.
query.result:
**English:**
127 These orders from above all admire themselves, 128 and from below they conquer so much, that towards God 129 all are drawn and all draw.
**Cornish:**
127 An urdhow ma a-ugh yw oll owth admir, 128 ha a-woles i a wra dheudh kemmys, dheudh Duw 129 oll yw tynset ha oll a dynn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 E Dïonisio con tanto disio 131 a contemplar questi ordini si mise, 132 che li nomò e distinse com’ io.
query.result:
**English:**
130 And Dionysius with such desire 131 set himself to contemplate these orders, 132 that he named and distinguished them as I do.
**Cornish:**
130 Ha Dionysios gans kemmys disir 131 a wra dheudh owth admir an urdhow ma, 132 ow henwis ha ow distinwis dell owth vy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Ma Gregorio da lui poi si divise; 134 onde, sì tosto come li occhi aperse 135 in questo ciel, di sé medesmo rise.
query.result:
**English:**
133 But Gregory then divided himself from him; 134 whence, as soon as he opened his eyes 135 in this heaven, he laughed at himself.
**Cornish:**
133 Mes Gregory a-wosa wosa dheudh parti 134; rag, kenjys e agoris y dhewlagas 135 yn an nef ma, ev a wra dheudh lowenj.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 E se tanto secreto ver proferse 137 mortale in terra, non voglio ch’ammiri: 138 ché chi ’l vide qua sù gliel discoperse
139 con altro assai del ver di questi giri».
query.result:
**English:**
136 And if a mortal on earth uttered so much secret truth, 137 I do not want you to marvel: 138 for he who saw it up here revealed it to him,
139 along with much else of the truth of these circles.
**Cornish:**
136 Ha mar kemmys a-ugh a leveris 137 mortal war an nor, nyns eus kar dheudh admir: 138 rag an neb a’n gwelas a-ugh a wra dheudh diskleri
139 gans meur a-ugh erel a-ugh an gwirioneth a’n hweel ma.
